sn24.18:3.1: 18 A Realized One Neither Exists Nor Doesn’t Exist
sn24.18:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.18:4.3: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’?”
sn24.18:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.18:5.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.18:5.2: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’ …
sn24.18:6.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.18:6.3: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.18:6.4: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’?”
sn24.18:6.6: “That which is seen, heard, thought, cognized, searched, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.18:6.8: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.18:6.10: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.18:6.11: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’?”
sn24.18:7.1: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt in these six cases, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.18:7.2: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
